discovery_rule.name: Discovery TCP LISTENING Port of processes

trigger_prototype.name: TCP LISTENING Port {#PROCTCPLISTEN} of {$PROC_NAME} is not connected on {HOST.NAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Zabbix agent couldn't connect to TCP {#PROCTCPLISTEN} of {$PROC_NAME}

discovery_rule.name: Discovery process infos
discovery_rule.description:
Args: command: process name(execute command)
Return: {#PROCNAME}... process name(execute command) {#PROCID}... pid {#PROCARG}...first argument of the command line(the second element of the command line)

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats cancelled_write_bytes item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
cancelled_write_bytes: The big inaccuracy here is truncate. If a process writes 1MB to a file and then deletes the file, it will in fact perform no writeout. But it will have been accounted as having caused 1MB of write. In other words: this field represents the number of bytes which this process caused to not happen, by truncating page‐ cache. A task can cause "negative" I/O too. If this task truncates some dirty pagecache, some I/O which another task has been accounted for (in its write_bytes) will not be happening.
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats rchar item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
rchar: characters read The number of bytes which this task has caused to be read from storage. This is simply the sum of bytes which this process passed to read(2) and similar system calls. It includes things such as terminal I/O and is unaffected by whether or not actual physical disk I/O was required (the read might have been satisfied from pagecache).
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats read_bytes item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
read_bytes: bytes read Attempt to count the number of bytes which this process really did cause to be fetched from the storage layer. This is accurate for block-backed filesystems.
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats syscr item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
syscr: read syscalls Attempt to count the number of read I/O operations—that is, system calls such as read(2) and pread(2).
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats syscw item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
syscw: write syscalls Attempt to count the number of write I/O operations— that is, system calls such as write(2) and pwrite(2).
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats wchar item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
whar: characters written The number of bytes which this task has caused, or shall cause to be written to disk. Similar caveats apply here as with rchar.
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats [$3] of $1 $2
item_prototype.description:
disk io stats write_bytes item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io
write_bytes: bytes written Attempt to count the number of bytes which this process caused to be sent to the storage layer.
see man of proc(5).

item_prototype.name: Disk IO stats master of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG}
item_prototype.description: disk io stats master item, which is gathered from /proc/[pid]/io

item_prototype.name: Memory used RSS of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG}
item_prototype.description:
Resident set size in physical memory. Data source is /proc/<pid>/status - VmRSS entry.
Procname is compared to 2 elements, the one /proc/<pid>/status the second /proc/<pid>/cmdline
Start with compare procname to /proc/<pid>/status - Name entrry. Having not matched above, turns to /proc/<pid>/cmdline. Note that /proc/<pid>/cmdline file may contain invisible null bytes, which termination of string in C.

item_prototype.name: Memory used swap of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG}
item_prototype.description:
size of swap space used. data source is that /proc/<pid>/status - the value of VmSwap:
Procname is compared to 2 elements, the one /proc/<pid>/status the second /proc/<pid>/cmdline
Start with compare procname to /proc/<pid>/status - Name entrry. Having not matched above, turns to /proc/<pid>/cmdline. Note that /proc/<pid>/cmdline file may contain invisible null bytes, which termination of string in C.

item_prototype.name: Memory used percentage RSS of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG}
item_prototype.description: used percentage rss of the total physical memory.

item_prototype.name: Process nums of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG}
item_prototype.description:
process numbers.
Procname is compared to 2 elements, the one /proc/<pid>/status the second /proc/<pid>/cmdline
Start with compare procname to /proc/<pid>/status - Name entrry. Having not matched above, turns to /proc/<pid>/cmdline. Note that /proc/<pid>/cmdline file may contain invisible null bytes, which termination of string in C.

trigger_prototype.name: Open files ratio of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG} overed {$INFO_OF}% on {HOST.NAME}
{#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG} process is not running on {HOST.NAME}
trigger_prototype.description: This is triggered when the number of {#PROCNAME} {#PROCARG} process was equal to 0
